sentence: Can Microsoft (MSFT) stock, which is trading at all-time highs, sustain its momentum?
That question will be answered when the world’s largest software company reports first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Thursday.
Currently trading at around $79, MSFT stock has been on fire, soaring 27% year to date, compared with a 14% rise for the S&P 500 index.
The stock has been rewarded, thanks to a combination of factors.

Aside from Microsoft’s string of eight straight earnings beats, which continues to exceed even the most bullish Wall Street expectations, its cloud-first strategy has emerged as a credible threat to Amazon’s (AMZN) dominant AWS cloud platform, pushing shares of the blue-chip Dow component up some 40% over the past year.
On Thursday, analysts will focus on the performance of Microsoft’s Intelligent Cloud services to assess if the momentum can continue into 2018.
For the quarter that ended September, the Redmond, Wash.-based tech giant is expected to deliver earnings per share of 72 cents on revenue of $23.53 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when the company earned 72 cents per share on $22.33 billion in revenue.
For the full year, earnings are projected to be $3.19 per share, down from $3.29 a year ago, while revenue of $104.55 billion would mark a year-over-year increase of 8.2%.
Once fully dependent on its Office and Windows franchises, Microsoft has fully transitioned towards its faster-growing cloud business.
In its fourth quarter, reported in July, Microsoft’s Commercial business, which includes products such as Office 365 and related cloud services revenue, rose 5% year over year.
When digging a bit deeper, it was even more remarkable that Office 365 commercial revenue surged 43%, while Office 365 posted 35% year-over-year rise in commercial seat growth.
These gains drove a 42% year-over-year surge in fourth quarter earnings per share of 98 cents, which not only rose 34% year over year, but also crushed Street estimates by 27 cents.

A beat of this magnitude underscores not only how profitable the cloud business continues to be, it also suggests Microsoft is holding its own against not just Amazon but also the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM) and IBM (IBM).
On Thursday, analysts will want to see evidence that Microsoft’s cloud growth can continue to accelerate into 2018.

Following its July report, Evercore analyst Kirk Materne issued a note, saying he expects Microsoft’s Azure to grow at around 70% to 80% in fiscal year 2018, citing new Azure features such as speech recognition and other tools, which he says brings Azure closer to Amazon’s AWS.

"While [Amazon Web Services] remains the clear leader in terms of public cloud computing today, one of the most notable takeaways from our meetings was the improving position of Azure, both as it relates to product maturity and market presence," Materne said.
On Thursday, however, how Microsoft guides for fiscal 2018 will determine what the stock does to close out the year.
From my vantage point, given the rate of revenue and profit growth, Microsoft continues to operate on all cylinders.
And it would be a mistake to part with this winner right now.
